Literature Review: Data integration in Bayesian phylogenetics has become a crucial aspect of modern evolutionary research, particularly in the study of viral pathogens and other organisms. The increasing availability of large and complex data sets from multiple sources has led to the development of sophisticated statistical models that can accommodate both discrete and continuous data. These models have enormous combined discrete/continuous parameter spaces, including phylogenetic tree topologies and branch lengths, and have spurred advances in computational methods to make them tractable. In this review, we will discuss the current state of data integration in Bayesian phylogenetics, including modeling and computational advances, as well as unsolved problems and areas of active research.
